Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Blending Ecology and Evolution using Emerging Technologies to Determine Species Distributions with a Non-native Pathogen in a Changing Climate
Award.AbstractNarration:
Predicting future distributions of plants on Earth is an urgent and daunting challenge, given the combined effects of climate change and invasive species, along with the fact that science does not fully understand how ecological and evolutionary processes interact across large areas. Southwestern white pine (SWP), a tree that occurs naturally from northern Arizona through central Mexico, is the focus of this project. Understanding its future depends on understanding biological processes at the molecular level, including the movement of genes, adaptations to disease and drought, and other heritable changes, interact in a changing environment interact to govern its overall success. But in addition, sustainability of SWP is threatened by a non-native tree disease called white pine blister rust. This project will develop tools to help forecast and manage the future of SWP, including genomic analyses, common garden trials where seedlings originating from different environments are planted together, screening for disease resistance, engineering and technology innovation to measure drought tolerance, and computer modeling that can integrate landscape ecology and genomics. The approach will also provide a prototype for forecasting complex system behavior that is more generally applicable.

The results of this project will contribute to the conservation of SWP and the ecosystems in which it occurs. White pine blister rust causes widespread tree decline and mortality in western North America, including the rapidly expanding area where it overlaps with SWP. It is quite possible that the climate will change too rapidly for SWP to adapt, causing widespread tree death and potential extinction. To help reach its goals, this project will also involve a number of educational and outreach activities, including exhibits and real common garden plantings at Flagstaff Arboretum in Arizona and the U.S. Forest Service Dorena Genetic Resource Center in Cottage Grove, Oregon. A number of postdoctoral scholars and graduate and undergraduate students will be trained and participate in interdisciplinary science that bridges genomics, tree disease resistance testing, landscape ecology, modeling, engineering, remote sensing, and spatial analysis. An outreach website and content will be developed in English and Spanish to provide results to the public, including land managers. Postdoctoral researchers will collaborate on a workshop for students in Mexico as part of their training. Workshops will also be developed for conferences in the Southwest, one of which will be a major cross-border meeting between Mexican and U.S. foresters. In short, this project will strengthen cross-border research, management efforts in forest conservation, and our understanding of how genetics shape life on Earth.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was to enhance understanding of how the distribution and conservation of a rare tree species is being affected by a non- native fungal pathogen in the context of a changing climate. This was accomplished using a blend of ecology and evolutionary biology combined with state-of-the-art imaging as well as UAV-based technologies for high-throughput phenotyping of experimental and natural plant populations. Many of the technologies were developed initially in agronomic settings, and we have adapted them for studying natural and unmanaged forests. This project also addressed numerous applied research questions, with wide implications for forest ecosystems in a rapidly warming world.

Tangible scientific outcomes of this project include: (1) advancing our understanding of how an invasive fungal pathogen impacts physiological function and survival of a rare tree species; (2) assessment of how this and similar species are likely to respond to a changing climate and disease threat; and (3) the establishment of new approaches for monitoring forest canopies, including rapid and accurate disease detection and assessment.

We found that there are several challenges using UAV imagery to estimate seedling size in common gardens. One primary challenge was the lack of spacing between seedlings resulting in crown overlap, which makes delineation of individual seedlings from the multispectral orthophotos difficult with time. We can recommend that seedlings be spaced at least 15 cm apart at planting to extend the time that UAVs can be used to survey the seedlings from two years in this study to at least four years.

We also found that using UAVs can reduce the number of manual measurements needed for seedling studies, which will reduce the time and diminish the costs needed to acquire the data. Another advantage of acquiring data with UAVs is consistency, as human error does not play a significant role in the quality of measurements. One of the major advantages of using UAV in the context of common gardens is that they have the potential to be much faster than traditional, manual measurements. While our methods were not perfect, we estimate that if the number of seedlings were about one order of magnitude higher, (i.e., n=1800) the total combined time of UAV field surveys, post-processing, and data extraction would be 25% less than the time required to record seedling sizes on the ground.

Our UAV remote sensing method presented a work flow for accurate and precise detection of seedling mortality. This methodology can be applied not only on common gardens but also in regeneration surveys, which would be another natural extension of this research.

Education outcomes were achieved by actively integrating research and education. This included training of post-doctoral scholars and mentoring of graduate and undergraduate students, as well as developing laboratory modules based on the concepts and datasets generated through this project for undergraduate- and graduate-level courses in geography, forestry, ecology, and environmental science. Robust public outreach was also conducted by multiple project participants in a variety of venues.
